ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 12. The class is likely more useful to those with backgrounds in (or interest in) international development and conservation, but i found it interesting and a challenge, even with my more "domestic policy" background.

Professor Carpenter was generous with her time and available to students. Conversation was lively and two-sided, which was very nice (as opposed to being talked at). Sometimes Professor Carpenter's explanations of concepts was difficult to follow; occasionally personal interpretations were presented as The One Answer (e.g. explanations of Foucault's concepts).Overall course content was helpful: this was my first encounter with many of these ideas, and I feel that I've been exposed to a totally new perspective and set of concerns that never would have been on my radar screen otherwise.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: This class definitely made me question the motives and achievements of government/development programs. While it can be depressing material to cover, it is crucial that anyone who wants to work in government be exposed to this way of thinking. I was able to look at a program I thought I knew very well from an entirely different perspective and see major flaws in its implementation. Though I am not pursuing this discipline academically, this class will definitely be useful in future professional work.

Thesis sentence requirement was cumbersome because it made it impossible to not do readings during busy weeks, yet this activity drove home concepts for me more than any other.In-class discussion was my favorite part of the course. Professor Carpenter fostered a lively back-and-forth that allowed room for expertise beyond her own (several classmates had implementation experience that put readings into other contexts) in a way that was both humble and increased the potential for student learning. It was the mark of a secure, learning-before-ego professor (a really nice change from others!).Teaching Fellow Erin Beasley was very available and helpful. She was a great TF who very much supported learning outside of class, especially in informal conversations. I very much enjoyed talking through readings with her.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Would have liked more feedback during the semester on the accuracy of my thesis sentences.
Choosing more readings that show positive or successful program implementation would be a nice balance!

The final paper doesn't need to be 25 pages, in my opinion. Concision can be prized (as it is with the twice-per-semester one-page assignments). Twenty five pages was more arduous than necessary to demonstrate understanding of the material.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: While there wasn't a discussion session per se, TF Erin Beasley regularly talked through readings with us, especially during the preparation session for student leadership of class discussion. Always this was directly related to class material and helpful--Erin was great at putting things into context and thinking conceptually.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course doesn't fit directly into my program. It may be that I complete a career never implementing a development project in an impoverished community. However, I gained an understanding of development--how it works, what challenges it faces, etc. This course definitely exposed me to the challenges, pitfalls, and red flags. Should I go into development, or should I find myself one day fortunate enough to be philanthropically giving to organizations implementing programs, I feel like I now have a much better toolkit for engagement that I would have if left to my own devices.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Originally I had wanted a toolkit to help me be better at implementation. In particular, I was hoping to find tools that would be applicable domestically as well as in international development contexts. I was hoping for recommended courses of action that I could put into my playbook: ways to determine appropriate targets for communication about a program, methods of communication that have worked to increase participation in a program vs. those that have acted to decrease participation, etc.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: This class was not at all what I expected it to be--I was expecting to analyze programs from an administrative perspective and be able to point out minor ways to save money, expand program coverage, or target recipients. This class taught me to question so much more, including the very existence of the programs I expected to analyze. This class exceeded expectations.

Yes, but in a far different direction that I'd expected at the outset. I was originally been looking for tools, or plays that I could include in my playbook (see answer to question 18). I was really thinking the course would be more pragmatic than it was. Instead of getting a list of "these are the good things to do," what I got from the course was a list of, "these are the things to look out for, and here's a companion list of things not to do." It was far more theoretical than pragmatic, which is helpful... albeit in a far different way than expected. Nevertheless, I learned a lot and am glad to have had the exposure to ideas I never would have sought out on my own otherwise.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The readings are always fascinating, but need to be read carefully (so make sure you have time for them).

For students working in developing nations or studying anthropology, this class will be directly applicable to you. For those with a background in management or politics, it will force you to take a critical look at your own work. However, if you have never taken an anthropology course before, maybe consider taking Carol's other, larger class.

Consider this class the theoretical framework that can inform your action. This is not a pragmatic class wherein you will get a set of tools for implementation. Instead, prepare yourself to think about bigger underlying questions of development project implementation. Knowledge gained in this class may be useful in developing your own playbook later, especially insofar as it may help you recognize gaps in your planning or approach, and may prove helpful in identifying reasons for project failure such that a program's trajectory can be fruitfully adjusted mid-course.I recommend this class for anyone who will be working in international aid/development programs. It may be less useful for those interested in implementing programs within already developed economies.
